content.description: A fun, but very inconsistent route.  Thoughtful 5.9-level moves up a very blocky/ledgy face through 6 bolts.  The crux is the last couple moves on the overhanging bulge at the top, punctuated by thin crimps that are hard to see and high feet.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: Five feet left of "Forest Circus Fiasco," second to last route along the approach path.  Look for a short, vertical very blocky face with a couple of large, overhanging boulders at the top.

content.description: Interesting and challenging at the crux, this route's section near the third clip is a bit perplexing.  Head up past these moves to more straight-forward face climbing.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: Five feet left of "Paul's Route."  Look for the same ramp and blocky overhang.  This route skirts the roof by moving left and up a shallow dihedral for the first couple bolts.

content.description: A decent warmup route.  Harder moves at the beginning and straight-forward climbing through the bolted section.
content.protection: Quickdraws, and cams for the first part of the route.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: Left of "Hostile Old Hikers."  Can be found on the other side of the outecropped rock where the aforementioned route begins.  Look for the bolt line that starts about 1/3 of the way up on a vertical face.

content.description: A good warm up route.  Fun climbing onto a ledge, straight-forward face climbing afterwards.
content.protection:
6 Quickdraws

Bolted anchors
content.location: 50 feet left of "Desert Dreaming."  Bolts all run straight up the face, however there's a big block that creates a left-sided dihedral at the start of this route.

content.description: A fun route with interesting moves, especially pulling the overhang (crux), protected by a cam.  Climb the short ramp, travel right while surmounting the roof, and climb up the face to the anchors above.
content.protection: Quickdraws and one small- to mid-sized cam.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: 30 feet left of "Molly's Route."  Look for a short ramp leading into a blocky overhang.

content.description: A fun, pumpy route with a longer (for OH8) section of overhung climbing.  Easy through the first couple bolts, and more demanding work on the upper, red face.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: 15 feet to the right of "The Shuttler."  The lower section of this route is on blocky/slabby black rock, and the upper half is red and a little overhung.  There's a ledge part way up that punctuates the change in rock coloring.

content.description: Begin up a fractured vertical face (there's a bolt at the top of the face, it's easy to miss), walk to the back of a deep ledge and ascend a second, more difficult face to the anchors.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a couple of cams.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Ten feet to the left of "Carl's Route."  The flat, short vertical face at the end of the rocky portion of the approach trail about midway along the crag.  The line can be harder to find, as the first bolt is at the top of the short face and somewhat hidden.

content.description: Fun, fairly easy climbing (10a-ish) until the final crack/bulge at the end of the route. Rewarding moves over a small roof early on, followed by chill face climbing.  The crux is the final couple moves through an overhang with a crack and interesting possible stem/mantle moves.
content.protection: Quickdraws and cams.  Midsized cam protects the crux at the end of the route.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Begins on a slabby ramp just to the left of the Buckwheat/Blind Ambition bolts.

content.description: Fairly non-descript route near the far end of the approach trail.  Typical OH8 block/slab/ledge climbing.
content.protection:
Quickdraws.  Bolted anchors.

The guidebook suggests a mid-sized cam placement part way up, but the locations for gear don't seem very good, and the next bolt is only another foot or two away, on a section of the route that is very easy climbing.
content.location: Five feet to the right of "Open Space Plan."  Slightly right-leaning bolt line.

content.description: Decent moves on interesting terrain, however some of the rock is loose, so those bomber hand holds you see from the ground may not be permanent fixtures.  This is an already fairly challenging trad route for the grade, so with poor quality rock, it may not be the most enjoyable of climbs.
content.protection: A couple of quickdraws, but mostly trad gear.  Larger cams  for the upper section, medium-sized ones for the first half.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Just to the left of "Ron Love Verly," begin on the outcropped face with a couple of very obvious vertical cracks.  Attain the ledge 1/3 of the way up and move right into the wider crack that veers right, towards the anchors of "Ron Love Verly."  Anchors are in the crack and above the finish of the aforementioned route.

content.description: Who put up the climb just to the right of Sasquatch. in that big corner.  I love it!!  really fun moving through the corner. bring gear also.
content.protection: mixed
content.location: just to the right of Sasquatch in the big corner that has black lichen.

content.description: It looks cute from the ground, but once you pass the first bolt, this diminutive little climb means business.  The crux can be found right after the second bolt, and forces a committing move on uncomfortably high feet and less than optimal hand holds.
content.protection: 3 quickdraws! Bolted anchor.
content.location: Short, squat, pot-bellied face right of, and close to "Risky Sex," about two thirds of the way down the approach trail.

content.description: Somewhat right facing, short route on slabby face through the first three bolts.  The crux is the demanding movement on the overhanging second block - from the third (and final) bolt to the anchor...utilizing tiny crimps on the face or a dirty left-sided arete (which is probably off route).  A fall near the anchor can result in decking on the ledge half way up the route, proceed carefully.
content.protection: 3 quickdraws.  Vertically bolted anchor, single quick link for rappel.
content.location: Another 50 feet past Spring Breezes.  Look for a large downed tree parallel to the cliff.  The Gap is the first bolt line near the tree.

content.description:
A fun, but frustratingly inconsistent route with an impressive, strong finishing move. Entertaining 5.8-level climbing up a very blocky/ledgy face through 6 bolts, followed by a crux that feels like a completely different climb.

The last couple moves of this route are on a severely overhanging bulge at the top. It requires the use of small crimps, a couple of slopers, a throw, and an awesome pull-up/mantle, with no foot holds. The single hardest move at the crag (?).

The crux can be circumvented by climbing the dirty crack to the left and traversing back onto the face of the bulge at the anchors (probably 5.9 or 5.10a climbing). Not recommended for fun factor, but a good way to get your gear back if you can't make the crux move on the face.
content.protection: Quickdraws. Bolted anchor.
content.location: Five feet right of "Bat Stupor," third to last route along the approach path. Look for a short, vertical very blocky face with a couple of large, overhanging boulders at the top.  "Forest Circus Fiasco" is the right bolt line on this face.

content.description:
Straight-forward climbing on this short, little route passing 3 bolts on the way to the anchor.

Not listed in the Oregon Rock Guidebook.
content.protection: Quickdraws, optional gear to 1" to protect the short run between the last bolt and the chains.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Just around the corner from Columbiana.  Leftmost route on the crag.

content.description:
Super fun route! The first half is 5.9 climbing through a satisfying dihedral onto a ledge.  The second half is face climbing over (or around) an overhang onto a sparse face with small holds.

A bit contrived near the top, as there is an alternate, 5.9 version that heads right and skirts the crux. Heading entirely left past the last two bolts seems a bit harder than 10d, however.
content.protection: Quickdraws and gear to 1.25". Bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: About 100 feet left of "Wind Dummy"/"Tidewater."  Look for a vertical red face split by three cracks that intersect to make an asterisk just above a scooped out roof.

content.description:
Entertaining moves through the first two bolts give way to mediocre, straight-forward, dirty face climbing on this seldom-touched little route.

Not listed in the Oregon Rock guidebook.
content.protection:
5 Quickdraws.

Bolted anchors.
content.location: Ten feet to the left of The Gap, near the far end of the large downed tree.

content.description: Fun climb punctuated by a crux in a small roof.  Difficulty of the route varies depending on which side of the bolt line you climb.  Left is easier.
content.protection: Quickdraws and midsize cams.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: 30 feet to the left of Penstemon.  Easy to locate: look for the chain hanging off the roof where the second bolt is placed

content.description:
This route has some stellar moves, and would easily be one of the best at OH8, except that it has a number of factors working against it.

One of the cam placements is right on top of a big sprig of poison oak that grows right out of the face, there's loose rock in the roof section at the top of the climb, and the anchors are a real pain to deal with.

If these items - and the fact that this rocky section of the path is a welcome home for rattlesnakes - does not deter, you'll find some truly engaging movement on the first face, followed by pumpy, jug throws to ascend the overhanging bulge at the end.
content.protection: Quickdraws and midsized cams.  Anchors are two bolts set one above the other with a chain running between the two.  One rap ring.  Not ideal.
content.location: About half way down the approach trail there is a second rocky section in the path.  Look for the bolt line in the middle of the face.

content.description: The lowest-graded route at OH8, and the only all-trad line.  Easy climbing up less than perfectly clean crack.  Great practice for placing cams!  Earns its name for an awkward move in a dihedral where it's easy to end up with your butt plastered to one of the walls!
content.protection: Lots of cams!  Trad crack route with ample gear placement opportunities.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Just left of "Risky Sex" in the slightly right-leaning crack.

content.description: An odd climb that weaves up and around some blank, slabby rock, then up a face to an interestingly placed anchor.
content.protection: Quickdraws, bolted anchors.
content.location:
Starts off just left of the Blind Ambition crack and climbs a gymnastic bolt protected pillar before transitioning on to a lichen covered slab. From the slab follow the bolt line up and slightly left to a set of anchors tucked into an overhanging block.

To avoid the loose blocks in the chimney at the top one can cut back right to clip the last bolt on Blind Ambition and finish on its' anchors; a much safer alternative.

content.description: A cool climb with a few fun, pumpy moves mixed with easy climbing.
content.protection: Quickdraws, small nut to protect the crux, and optional cams for upper portion of the climb.  Bolted anchors.
content.location:
Rightmost route on the crag.  Shaded by a couple of oak trees.

Start on the crack right of Buckwheat. Then follow the bolts up the face.

(Instead of using the bottom crack for trad protection, some may instead use the first bolt or two of Buckwheat.)

content.description: Climb up some awkward moves past a low first bolt. A cam will protect between the second to third bolts if so desired but the holds are chunky and some will do without it. Half way up the climb there is a large ledge and a chimney. Wind Dummy follows the line of bolts going up and slightly left. The crux hits one or two bolts up with some thinner moves on a more vertical face.
content.protection: Quickdraws, optional gear to 1" to sew up the space between a couple of bolts low on the route.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Begins 15 feet left of Sasquatch, shares the same start with Tidewater and can be identified by a low first bolt.

content.description:
Climb up some awkward moves past a low first bolt. A cam will protect between the second to third bolts if so desired but the holds are chunky and some will do without it. Half way up the climb there is a large ledge and a chimney. Tidewater splits off to the right and another smaller cam will protect the leader before following up a line of bolts on the arete. The crux hits one or two bolts after the route splits off right from it's twin route, Wind Dummy, with a move or two that establishes the climber on the arete/face to the right.

A decent warmup and easiest climb at OH8.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a couple pieces of gear: one cam or nut after the first bolt and another to protect the crux half way up. Anchors are bolted vertically with a chain connecting, and one rap ring.
content.location: Begins 15 feet left of Sasquatch. Half way up the cliff face there's a ledge and a ravine, and the route splits into two. Follow the right bolt line that climbs the face/arete right next to Sasquatch.

content.description: Easy climbing gives way to a couple of face moves on thin hand holds part way up.  Once past the middle section it's easier climbing to the anchors.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a couple smaller cams.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: 30 feet left of "Reed's Route," a somewhat right-leaning route on slightly slabby face.

content.description:
An odd, short little climb that has some challenging moves if you force yourself to stay on/right of the bolt line.  Head up the initial bulge on small crimps, surmount an overhang using an undercling with a large reach to some less-than-bomber holds.  And then you're basically done, as the last 10-15 feet of the route is 5.6 slab climbing.

Heading a couple feet left at the start and using the big blocks and the crack results in a climb that is probably 5.8.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  Bolted anchor.
content.location:
About 50 feet past "Bat Stupor" and "Forest Circus Fiasco." Anchors visible from the approach (you'll likely see them well before you see the bolt line, as the start of the route is sheilded by small oak trees).

This route is not listed in the Oregon Rock guidebook.

content.description: Easy, 5.8 block/ledge climbing up to the last bolt.  Final moves surmounting the overhang/nose feature at the top of the route are where it earns the grade.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Near the end of the approach trail, 20 feet right of "Forest Circus Fiasco", at the bottom of a dip in the trail.  Easily recognized by the large pointy "nose" that sticks up  at the top of the route (looks a bit like something out of a Dr. Seuss landscape).

content.description:
Easily the best route at OH8, and probably the most consistently difficult at the crag.  This long, exciting route has a little of everything.  Three crux sections will quickly make themselves obvious when climbing this route for the first time:

The moves off the deck through the first slab section and up to the second bolt are very thin, technical and crimpy.  Climbing only the face here earns the grade, though climbing left for a safe first clip and gear placement won't spoil the route.

The second crux hits about half way up with a specific sequence of larger moves to attain a ledge.

The sequence for pulling the final roof constitutes the final crux, mostly for the larger moves and pump factor...but it's also the best part!
content.protection: Quickdraws, cams in 1-2" range, some small pieces for easier corner start. Bolted anchors.
content.location: 15 feet right of Tidewater/Wind Dummy.  The tallest climb in the vicinity.  Look for a big, undulating red/orange face with a wide horizontal black stripe about 3/4 of the way up the route.

content.description: A short route that's harder than it looks, and much less fun than it should be.  Begin on a slab with disappointing holds (they look good, but they just aren't what they advertise).  Move up to a short, non-descript face climb with a couple obvious gear placmements to the anchors.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a couple mid- to large-sized cams.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: 40 feet to the left of "Molly's Route." Begins on an outcropped slab with interesting looking facets.

content.description: Great warmup route!  More consistently technical than most at OH8.  Intersting stem/reach moves to get past the second clip, and a crux onto a thin slab near the end that will get your blood pumping!
content.protection: 6 bolts & bolted top anchor
content.location: The easiest route at OH8 to identify (and a bit sad), as the route is named after the graffiti on the route's large first block.  Just to the left of "Just a Freakin' Rock Climber", third bolt line from the right on the crag.

content.description: This is a 2 bolt extension to Ron Love Verly, to an independent anchor.
content.protection: bolts
content.location: 2 routes right of where the trail from the road comes up.

content.description: Great climbing with fun features down low on a small roof and an arete.  Surmounting the bare bulge at the top of the route is the crux.
content.protection: Quickdraws, and one smaller cam placement low on the route.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: About 25 feet left of "Get it, Shorty."  It looks like a route you'd want to climb given the features through the first two bolts, about 2/3 of the way down the approach path.
